content.description: Climb the featured face just left of Leapin’ Lizard, finishing up the arete.
content.protection: Beech tree far back for top anchor, closer boulder for directional.

content.description: Boulder located just to the West, continuing in an upriver direction from the top of the crag, trending up a bit. There is a mossy face split by cracks, facing the river, with good climbing on the left side. Some climbing is also possible in the corridor behind the boulder. Easy scramble off the back.
content.protection: Okay landing. Easy scramble off back.
content.location: Head West (upriver) from the top of Fox Hill Crag. It is not much of a bushwhack, but no trail has been established.

content.description: Climb the center of the tallest section of rock. Variations can be contrived by using holds to either side, or several distinct paths are possible by sticking to a narrow lane, for a greater challenge. Rated by a nine year old, and not repeated, but he downgraded from his original 5.7/8 assessment. Taller individuals may not be required to do the lizard leap at the top.
content.protection: Trees far back from edge, with a closer boulder possible for use as a directional.
content.location: Tallest and cleanest vertical rock here. This is the king line, for this pawn crag, with a number of fun variations.

content.description: Low crux **beta alert** with hidden undercling. Using the corner or right wall will make the going easier, as will reaching far left to the arete.
content.protection: Tree a bit back from top. Boulder possible for backup or directional.
content.location: Climb the slightly shorter face, left of a left facing corner, left of Leapin’ Lizard.

content.description: Secluded, small North-facing crag. Mostly shaded and high enough above the river to not be too buggy.
